title: Two-thirds of savers cash in pension pots
text:
Osborne under pressure to cut bank tax 
The rules allow people to withdraw their whole pension pot from age 55, with the first 25 per cent tax free and the remaining 75 per cent taxed at the saver’s marginal rate. 
More than 85,000 have used the opportunity to withdraw money from their pension pots so far, according to the Treasury, and nearly a million others have visited the Government Pension Wise website to look into their options. 
Royal London said 16 per cent of the 800 customers it interviewed planned to use the cash to pay off their mortgage or other debts, while 32 per cent said they intended to leave the cash with a bank or building society. 
However, depending on their income and how big their pension pot is, people choosing to take their pensions as cash in one go will pay substantial tax, Royal London has warned. 
“Where customers are looking to pay off debts or spend the money on a vital purchases, the tax charge may well be a price worth paying,” said Fiona Tait, a pension specialist at Royal London . 
“However, if the intention is for cash to just stay in a savings account, consumers are potentially paying a tax charge for no additional financial benefit.” People want the security of being able to access the money when they like without restrictions 
- Anna Bowes, Savings Champion 
The average size of a pension pot being accessed was £15,500, which is in line with figures released by the Association of British Insurers last month. The average size of a fund being fully cashed in by Royal London customers was slightly lower at £14,100. Based on these figures the initial tax charge would be £3,347, because the cash lump sum would be subject to emergency tax on payment. 
Anna Bowes, director of rate monitoring website Savings Champion, said she is seeing an increasing number of people cashing in their pension pots. “People understand cash better than pensions and investments and want the security of being able to access the money when they like without restrictions,” she said. 
Others cite the emotional pull of cash. Tom McPhail, head of pensions research at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: “People like the idea of taking cash from their pension funds without necessarily thinking about what they will do with the money. 
“The smaller the pension pot the more likely it is that the saver will take all their cash in one go. This is because the level of income you can generate from a pot of this size is very small.” Related Topics
